description: From Middle English wyn, win, from Old English wīn, from Proto-West Germanic *wīn, from Proto-Germanic *wīną, from Latin vīnum, from Proto-Indo-European *wóyh₁nom (“wine”). Doublet of vine.

entries.meaning: An alcoholic beverage made by fermenting grape juice, with an ABV ranging from 5.5–16%.
examples: ...selle mon... mittan fulne huniges oðða tuegen uuines...

entries.meaning: An alcoholic beverage made by fermenting other substances, producing a similar ABV.

examples: I'd like three beers and two wines, please. My friend will have the same.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The color of red wine, a deep reddish purple.

verbs.description: wine (third-person singular simple present wines, present participle wining, simple past and past participle wined)

examples: Neither Major Wadhams nor I is accustomed to being wined and dined by perfect strangers who do not even present themselves, but leave servants to do the honors, consequently to both of us our present situation smacks of romance and adventure;

description: A variant of wind with simplification of the final consonant cluster; for the vowel quality, compare find, mind, rind.
